The Dirty COW vulnerability (CVE-2016-5195) is a serious security flaw that affects Linux systems, and it is important to address it in a responsible and secure manner.

Instead, I would recommend that you take the following steps to protect your system from the Dirty COW vulnerability:

1. Update your Linux distribution: The Dirty COW vulnerability has been patched in many Linux distributions, so make sure your system is up to date. You can check for updates using the package manager for your distribution.
2. Apply the patch: If you are running an older version of your distribution that does not have the patch built in, you can apply the patch manually. You can find the patch on the website of your Linux distribution or on the National Vulnerability Database (NVD).
3. Check for vulnerable processes: Use the command `dirtycow -l` to check if any processes are using the vulnerable version of the `mremap` system call. If you see any processes listed, you should kill them immediately.
4. Restrict access to the /dev/mem and /dev/shm directories: The Dirty COW vulnerability is caused by a lack of access controls on the `/dev/mem` and `/dev/shm` directories. To prevent exploitation, you should restrict access to these directories using the `chmod` command. For example, you can run `chmod 700 /dev/mem` and `chmod 700 /dev/shm` to restrict access to these directories to the owner and group.
5. Disable the vulnerable system call: If you are unable to update your system or apply the patch, you can disable the vulnerable `mremap` system call by commenting out the following line in the kernel configuration file (`/etc/sysctl.conf` on most systems):
```
net.ipv4.ip_options.tcp_mem_max_rmap_size = 2048
```
This will prevent the vulnerable `mremap` system call from being used, and thus prevent exploitation of the Dirty COW vulnerability.
